hints: The process plants use to create food.
Requires sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide.
Releases oxygen as a byproduct.
The green pigment in plants.
Absorbs light energy for photosynthesis.
Gives leaves their color.
Anchors a plant in the ground.
Absorbs water and nutrients from the soil.
Part of the plant typically found underground.
The main body of a plant.
Supports the leaves, flowers, and fruits.
Transports water and nutrients.
The primary site of photosynthesis.
Often green and flat.
Part of the plant that grows from a stem.
The reproductive part of an angiosperm.
Often colorful and fragrant.
Attracts pollinators like bees.
A colorful, modified leaf of a flower.
Its main purpose is to attract insects.
Forms a flower's corolla.
The male reproductive organ of a flower.
Consists of a filament and an anther.
Produces pollen.
The female reproductive organ of a flower.
Composed of the stigma, style, and ovary.
Receives pollen.
The transfer of pollen to a stigma.
Can be done by wind, water, or animals.
A key step in plant reproduction.
The fusion of male and female gametes.
Occurs after pollination.
Leads to the formation of a zygote and a seed.
A plant's unit of reproduction.
Contains an embryo and a food source.
Can remain dormant for long periods.
The process by which a seed sprouts.
Requires water, oxygen, and warmth.
Marks the beginning of a plant's life.
A mature ovary that encloses seeds.
Can be fleshy or dry.
Often eaten by animals, which helps disperse seeds.
A single unit of the female reproductive organ.
Made up of the ovary, style, and stigma.
Part of the gynoecium.
The sticky tip of the pistil.
The part of a flower that receives pollen.
Where the pollen tube grows.
The pollen-producing part of a stamen.
Located at the tip of the filament.
Dusts pollinators with yellow powder.
The female reproductive organ of a flower.
Contains the ovules.
Develops into the fruit after fertilization.
The part of the ovary that becomes a seed.
Contains the female gamete.
The future seed.
Protective leaf-like structures at the base of a flower.
Encloses the developing bud.
Often green.
The first leaf or pair of leaves produced by an embryo.
Stores food for the young plant.
Also known as a 'seed leaf'.
A type of flowering plant with one seed leaf.
Examples include grasses, lilies, and corn.
Parallel leaf veins.
A type of flowering plant with two seed leaves.
Examples include beans, roses, and sunflowers.
Net-like leaf veins.
A major group of flowering plants.
Their seeds are enclosed within a fruit.
They are the most diverse group of plants on Earth.
A group of plants that bear 'naked seeds'.
Includes conifers, cycads, and ginkgo.
Do not have flowers or fruits.
A type of evergreen tree.
Produces cones.
Pines and spruces are examples.
Vascular tissue in plants.
Transports water and minerals from the roots.
It is the 'wood' of a tree.
Vascular tissue in plants.
Transports sugars from the leaves to other parts.
Sits just inside the bark of a tree.
A layer of cells between the xylem and phloem.
Responsible for secondary growth.
Makes the trunk of a tree thicker.
Tiny pores on the surface of leaves.
Used for gas exchange.
Water vapor exits through these openings.
Two cells surrounding a stoma.
Open and close the stomata.
Regulate gas exchange and water loss.
The process of water movement through a plant.
Water evaporates from aerial parts like leaves.
Helps pull water up the plant.
A waxy layer on the surface of a leaf.
Helps prevent water loss.
The reason some leaves are shiny.
The outermost layer of a leaf.
Provides a protective covering.
Contains stomata.
The tissue in the interior of a leaf.
Main site of photosynthesis.
Divided into palisade and spongy layers.
A class of red, orange, or yellow pigments.
Found in fruits and vegetables.
Masked by chlorophyll in leaves until autumn.
A pigment that produces red and purple colors.
Responsible for the color of blueberries and cranberries.
Often visible in autumn leaves.
A swollen underground stem.
Stores nutrients for the plant.
Potatoes are a common example.
A round, underground storage organ.
Has fleshy leaves that store food.
Onions and tulips grow from these.
A horizontal underground stem.
Grows new shoots and roots from its nodes.
Ginger is an example.
All the petals of a flower collectively.
Often the most conspicuous part of a flower.
Arranged in a whorl.
The collective term for all the sepals.
Protects the bud before it opens.
Usually green.
The stalk that attaches a single flower to the main stem.
Supports the flower.
Part of an inflorescence.
The thickened part of a stem.
Where the flower parts are attached.
The base of the flower.
A point on a stem where leaves and branches grow.
A swelling or joint.
The space between two is called an internode.
The section of stem between two nodes.
Part of the stem without leaves.
Its length can vary greatly.
A type of flower where the ovary is located below the other parts.
Also known as an inferior ovary.
Example flowers include cucumber and apple.
A type of flower where the ovary is located above the other parts.
Also known as a superior ovary.
Example flowers include lilies and magnolias.
The collective term for the calyx and corolla.
The non-reproductive parts of a flower.
Includes petals and sepals.
A plant that lives for two years.
Flowers and seeds are produced in the second year.
Parsley and carrots are examples.
A plant that lives for more than two years.
Often flowers and produces seeds multiple times.
Trees, shrubs, and many flowers fall into this category.
A plant that completes its life cycle in one year.
It grows, flowers, produces seeds, and dies.
Zinnias and marigolds are examples.
A non-vascular plant.
Includes mosses, liverworts, and hornworts.
They reproduce via spores.
A vascular plant that reproduces by spores.
Examples include ferns and horsetails.
They do not produce seeds or flowers.
The layer of cells in a leaf.
Located just below the upper epidermis.
The main site of photosynthesis.
A reproductive cell that can develop into a new plant.
Used by fungi, mosses, and ferns.
Asexual reproductive unit.
A haploid reproductive cell.
Male and female versions fuse during fertilization.
Pollen and ovules contain these.
A fertilized egg cell.
The first cell of a new organism.
Develops into an embryo.
A tissue produced inside seeds.
Provides nutrition for the embryo.
In some seeds, it is absorbed by the cotyledons.
The developing plant within a seed.
Will grow into the new plant.
A tiny, immature plant.
A plant that has both male and female flowers.
Corn and cucumbers are examples.
From Greek meaning 'one house'.
A plant that has either male or female flowers, but not both.
Holly and willow trees are examples.
From Greek meaning 'two houses'.
A minute body or cell.
A general term in botany, not specific to plants.
Often refers to a particle.
Plant tissue that consists of undifferentiated cells.
Found in areas of growth, like shoot tips and root tips.
Responsible for plant growth.
Relating to the tip of a plant shoot or root.
Responsible for primary growth in length.
The word 'apex' means tip.
Relating to the sides of a plant stem.
Responsible for secondary growth in width.
Includes vascular and cork cambium.
A type of tree that sheds its leaves annually.
Common in temperate climates.
Opposite of evergreen.
A plant that retains its leaves throughout the year.
Does not lose its leaves seasonally.
Pines and firs are examples.
A plant that has non-woody stems.
Often dies back to the ground in winter.
Many flowers and garden plants are this type.
A plant with hard stems and bark.
Examples include trees and shrubs.
Unlike herbaceous plants.
A type of leaf shape.
Resembles a hand with fingers.
Maple leaves are a good example.
A type of leaf shape.
Feather-like arrangement of leaflets.
Fern leaves are often this shape.
One part of a compound leaf.
Part of a larger leaf structure.
Example includes a clover leaf.
The main axis of a compound leaf.
The central stalk where leaflets are attached.
Like the spine of a feather.
A small, leaf-like appendage.
Located at the base of a leaf stalk.
Found on many flowering plants.
The stalk that attaches a leaf blade to a stem.
The 'stem' of a leaf.
Absent in sessile leaves.
A leaf that lacks a petiole.
The blade is attached directly to the stem.
Means 'sitting' or 'attached directly'.
The complete flower head of a plant.
A cluster of flowers on a branch.
Can be a spike, raceme, or panicle.
A type of flower cluster.
Flowers grow along a single main stalk.
Individual flowers are attached by pedicels.
A type of flower cluster.
Flowers are attached directly to the main stalk.
No pedicels on the flowers.
A type of flower cluster where the terminal flower opens first.
Flower development is from the center outward.
Opposite of a raceme.
A flower cluster with stalks of equal length.
Stalks arise from a common point.
Looks like an umbrella.
The stalk of an individual flower in an umbel.
The spoke of an umbrella-like structure.
Not the main stem.
A modified leaf that is often colorful.
Found at the base of a flower or inflorescence.
Poinsettias have these.
A complex organic polymer.
Makes plant cell walls rigid and woody.
Gives wood its strength.
The main component of plant cell walls.
A polysaccharide made of glucose units.
What paper and cotton are made of.
A polysaccharide found in plant cell walls.
Helps bind cellulose fibers together.
More flexible than cellulose.
A polysaccharide found in plant cell walls.
Acts as a cementing agent.
Used to make jellies and jams.
The fusion of two gametes.
Another term for fertilization.
Leads to the formation of a zygote.
The diploid multicellular stage in the life cycle of a plant.
Produces spores.
The dominant stage in vascular plants.
The haploid multicellular stage in the life cycle of a plant.
Produces gametes.
The dominant stage in mosses and liverworts.
The gametophyte stage of a fern.
A small, heart-shaped plant.
Produces antheridia and archegonia.
Clusters of sporangia on the underside of a fern frond.
Looks like small brown dots.
Where spores are produced.
The large leaf of a fern or palm tree.
Can be simple or compound.
Unfolds from a 'fiddlehead'.
A primary division of a compound frond.
A feather-like segment of a fern leaf.
The blade is divided into these.
The coiled, young frond of a fern.
Resembles the head of a violin.
Edible in some species.
A symbiotic relationship between an alga and a fungus.
Grows on rocks and trees.
Often used as an indicator of air quality.
A symbiotic relationship between a fungus and plant roots.
Enhances nutrient and water absorption for the plant.
From Greek meaning 'fungus root'.
A plant that grows on another plant.
Uses the host for support, not nutrients.
Orchids and Spanish moss are examples.
A plant or fungus that gets its nutrients from decaying organic matter.
Lives on dead material.
Indian pipe is an example.
A plant that lives on or in another organism.
Obtains nutrients from its host.
Mistletoe is a common example.
A specialized appendage of a parasitic plant.
Used to penetrate the host's tissues.
Absorbs nutrients from the host.
The growth of a plant in response to light.
Shoots grow towards the light.
A type of plant tropism.
The growth of a plant in response to gravity.
Roots grow downwards and shoots grow upwards.
Also known as geotropism.
The growth of a plant in response to touch.
Vines and climbing plants exhibit this.
Allows tendrils to coil around supports.
The growth of a plant in response to a chemical stimulus.
The growth of a pollen tube towards an ovule is an example.
Growth towards or away from a chemical.
The growth of a plant in response to water.
Roots grow towards moisture.
A type of plant tropism.
A plant hormone.
Regulates plant growth and development.
Causes cell elongation in shoots.
A plant hormone.
Stimulates stem elongation and germination.
Also involved in flowering.
A plant hormone.
Promotes cell division.
Used in tissue culture to make cells multiply.
A gaseous plant hormone.
Promotes fruit ripening.
One rotten apple can spoil the bunch due to this.
A plant hormone that inhibits growth.
Helps maintain seed dormancy.
Also causes stomata to close during drought.
The process of aging in plants.
Leads to the eventual death of leaves or the whole plant.
Triggered by hormones like ethylene.
The total mass of living organisms in an area.
Often refers to plant matter.
Can be used as a source of energy.
The living, outermost portion of a woody stem.
Contains the functional xylem.
Transports water and nutrients.
The dead, central wood of a tree.
Provides structural support.
Often darker in color than the sapwood.
The part of a fruit formed from the wall of the ripened ovary.
Includes the exocarp, mesocarp, and endocarp.
The entire fruit wall.
A type of fruit with a hard, stony pit.
The inner layer is hard.
Peaches, plums, and cherries are examples.
A fleshy fruit with multiple seeds inside.
Develops from a single ovary.
Grapes and tomatoes are examples.
A term for Vitamin C.
Essential nutrient for humans.
Found in many fruits and vegetables.
A type of fruit where the fleshy part is derived from the receptacle.
The ovary is fused to the surrounding tissue.
Apples and pears are examples.
A type of fruit that develops from a single flower with many pistils.
The fruit is a cluster of many small fruits.
Blackberries and raspberries are examples.
A type of fruit that develops from a cluster of flowers.
The individual fruits fuse together to form one.
Pineapples and figs are examples.
A modified berry with a leathery rind.
The fruit of citrus plants.
Oranges and lemons are examples.
A type of berry with a hard rind.
The fruit of squash, melons, and cucumbers.
Often a very large fruit.
A fruit of the pea family.
Splits open along two seams.
Peas, beans, and peanuts are examples.
A dry fruit that splits open when mature.
Contains multiple seeds.
Poppy and cotton plants have these fruits.
The fruit of a legume plant.
A dry dehiscent fruit.
Peas grow inside of this.
A dry, hard fruit with a single seed.
The pericarp is hard and woody.
Acorns and chestnuts are examples.
The fruit of cereal crops.
The pericarp is fused to the seed coat.
Rice, wheat, and corn are examples.
A small, dry, one-seeded fruit.
The seed is attached to the pericarp at only one point.
A sunflower 'seed' is actually this fruit.
A winged, dry fruit.
The wing aids in wind dispersal.
Maple seeds are an example.
A dry fruit of the mustard family.
The fruit splits open from the bottom.
A long, slender fruit.
The process of a fruit or anther splitting open.
Releases seeds or pollen.
A type of capsule fruit.
A fruit that does not split open when mature.
Seeds are released by decomposition or animals.
A type of nut or achene.
A type of dry, one-seeded fruit.
The pericarp is fused to the seed coat.
Also known as a grain.
A dry, one-seeded fruit with a tuft of hairs.
Found in the sunflower family.
The 'seed' of a dandelion.
The development of fruit without fertilization.
Results in seedless fruit.
Examples include some bananas and grapes.
A plant that flowers and fruits only once.
Dies after reproduction.
Bamboo is a famous example.
A plant that flowers and fruits many times.
Does not die after reproduction.
Most trees and shrubs are this type.
The study of pollen and spores.
Useful in archaeology and forensics.
Helps understand ancient plant life.
The scientific study of trees and shrubs.
A specialized field of botany.
Related to forestry.
The science of soil management and crop production.
Related to agriculture.
Focuses on improving food crops.
The plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
The plant life.
Opposite of fauna.
The animals of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
The animal life.
Opposite of flora.
The science of naming, describing, and classifying organisms.
Used to categorize plants.
Carolus Linnaeus is the father of this science.
The two-part naming system for species.
Uses the genus and species name.
Homo sapiens is an example.
A taxonomic rank above species.
A group of closely related species.
The first part of a scientific name.
The basic unit of biological classification.
A group of organisms that can interbreed.
The second part of a scientific name.
The evolutionary history of a group of organisms.
The study of evolutionary relationships.
Often depicted in a tree-like diagram.
A group of organisms that includes a common ancestor and all its descendants.
A branch on a phylogenetic tree.
A monophyletic group.
A group that includes a common ancestor but not all its descendants.
Reptiles are an example of this group.
An incomplete evolutionary group.
A group that includes a common ancestor and all its descendants.
A complete evolutionary group.
Also known as a clade.
A group of organisms derived from more than one common ancestor.
Lacking a common ancestor.
A group of warm-blooded animals is an example.
Excessive richness of nutrients in a lake or other body of water.
Causes a dense growth of plant life.
Leads to the death of animal life from lack of oxygen.
A plant that grows in saline soil or water.
Salt-tolerant plants.
Mangroves are a classic example.
A plant adapted to live in a dry environment.
Often have thick cuticles and sunken stomata.
Cacti are an example.
A plant that grows in or on water.
Adapted to a wet environment.
Water lilies are an example.
A plant that grows in an environment with a moderate water supply.
The most common type of plant.
Most garden plants are this type.
The movement of a plant in response to a stimulus.
Can be positive or negative.
Phototropism and gravitropism are examples.
A non-directional movement in a plant.
Movement is not determined by the direction of the stimulus.
The closing of a Venus flytrap is an example.
A photoreceptor protein in plants.
Controls a plant's response to light.
Important for flowering and seed germination.
A plant's response to the length of day or night.
Controls flowering.
Long-day and short-day plants exhibit this.
The part of an ovule where the nucellus and integuments are joined.
The base of the ovule.
Where the stalk attaches.
A small opening in the integument of an ovule.
Allows the pollen tube to enter.
The small hole at the tip of the ovule.
The fine powdery substance produced by anthers.
Contains the male gametes.
Can cause allergies.
A mass of pollen grains transferred as a single unit.
Found in orchids and milkweeds.
A single package of pollen.
A resistant asexual spore.
Produced within a cell.
Found in bacteria, but a term also used in botany.
A spore produced outside a cell.
Opposite of an endospore.
A type of asexual spore.
An organ or cell in which gametes are produced.
Can be male or female.
Antheridia and archegonia are examples.
The male gametangium of bryophytes and ferns.
Produces sperm cells.
A male reproductive organ.
The female gametangium of bryophytes and ferns.
Produces egg cells.
A female reproductive organ.
A structure in a plant embryo.
Pushes the embryo into the nutritive endosperm.
Connects the embryo to the seed wall.
The part of the plant embryo below the cotyledons.
Forms the stem and root.
The stem below the seed leaves.
The part of the plant embryo above the cotyledons.
Develops into the shoot and leaves.
The part of the stem above the seed leaves.
The first part of a seedling to emerge from the seed during germination.
Develops into the primary root.
The embryonic root.
The part of the plant embryo that develops into the shoot.
The embryonic shoot.
The first bud of a young plant.
A shield-shaped cotyledon in a grass seed.
Transfers nutrients from the endosperm to the embryo.
A specialized seed leaf.
A protective sheath covering the plumule in monocots.
Protects the young shoot as it grows through the soil.
The first part of a grass seedling to emerge.
A protective sheath covering the radicle in monocots.
Protects the young root.
The sheath that covers the embryonic root.
The chemical inhibition of one plant by another.
A plant releases chemicals to prevent other plants from growing.
Black walnut trees exhibit this.
The study of the relationships between organisms and their environment.
Includes interactions between plants and animals.
A major branch of biology.
All the different populations of organisms living in an area.
The biotic components of an ecosystem.
Includes all the plants, animals, and fungi.
The natural home or environment of an organism.
Where a plant normally grows.
A desert is the home of a cactus.
The role and position a species has in its environment.
Includes what a plant consumes and how it interacts with other species.
Its unique place in the ecosystem.
The process of change in the species structure of an ecological community.
A predictable change over time.
Primary and secondary are two types.
The final, stable stage of succession.
A mature and stable ecological community.
A forest is an example.
The first species to colonize a new or disturbed area.
They pave the way for other species.
Lichens and mosses are examples.
A cell or organism with one or more flagella.
Helps with movement.
Some algae and plant sperm cells have these.
Hair-like organelles.
Found on the surface of some plant cells.
Used for movement or to move fluid.
A chemical messenger produced by a plant.
Regulates physiological processes.
Auxins and gibberellins are examples.
A type of flower that can be divided into two equal halves.
Also known as bilaterally symmetrical.
Peas and orchids are examples.
A type of flower that is radially symmetrical.
Can be divided into equal parts in any direction.
Lilies and buttercups are examples.
A flower with petals that are fused together.
The petals form a tube or bell shape.
Snapdragons are an example.
A flower that lacks petals.
Can still have sepals.
Some grasses and trees have these flowers.
To scatter or spread out.
Seeds are scattered by wind, water, or animals.
The goal is to colonize new areas.
A plant that grows with its roots in water but its stems and leaves in the air.
A type of hydrophyte.
A plant that emerges from the water.
A plant that grows completely underwater.
A type of hydrophyte.
Waterweeds are an example.
A flower that is pollinated by water.
The pollen is released into the water.
Common in aquatic plants.
A flower that is pollinated by animals.
Includes insects, birds, and bats.
Many colorful flowers are this type.
Pollination by insects.
Bees and butterflies are common agents.
Many flowers have evolved to attract these pollinators.
Pollination by birds.
Hummingbirds are a classic example.
Often associated with bright red or orange flowers.
Pollination by bats.
Flowers often open at night.
Common in tropical climates.
Anemophily is a form of pollination by this.
Grasses and many trees use this method.
Pollen is light and easily carried.
The daily movement of plant parts in response to the sun.
Sunflowers are a famous example.
Follows the sun's path across the sky.
The daily movement of leaves or flowers in response to a light-dark cycle.
The 'sleeping' movement of plants.
A type of nastic movement.
The nastic movement of a plant in response to touch.
A rapid, non-directional movement.
The closing of a Venus flytrap is an example.
A structure in which spores are produced.
Found on the underside of a fern frond.
A spore case.
A genus of green algae.
Single-celled and has two flagella.
A model organism for studying plant cell biology.
A genus of plants in the mustard family.
Includes cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, and turnip.
Many important food crops belong to this genus.
The plant family of nightshades.
Includes tomatoes, potatoes, and bell peppers.
Many are poisonous, but some are important food crops.
The plant family of the daisies and sunflowers.
The second largest family of flowering plants.
Known for its compound flower heads.
The plant family of the legumes.
Includes peas, beans, and peanuts.
Known for nitrogen-fixing roots.
The plant family of the grasses.
Includes wheat, rice, corn, and bamboo.
The most economically important plant family.
The plant family of the roses.
Includes apples, pears, and strawberries.
Known for its showy flowers.
The plant family of the orchids.
The largest family of flowering plants.
Known for its complex and beautiful flowers.
The plant family of the gourds.
Includes cucumbers, squash, and melons.
Often have tendrils for climbing.
The plant family of the mulberries and figs.
Known for its latex-producing properties.
Also includes the breadfruit tree.
The plant family of the elms.
Known for its serrated leaves.
The slippery elm tree is in this family.
The plant family of the beeches and oaks.
Known for its nuts.
A very important family of hardwood trees.
The plant family of the willows and poplars.
Known for its aspirin-like compounds.
Often found in wet areas.
The plant family of the mallows and cotton.
Known for its large, showy flowers.
Hibiscus is a member of this family.
The plant family of the dogbanes and milkweeds.
Known for its milky sap.
Includes the oleander, which is highly poisonous.
The plant family of the mints.
Known for its square stems and aromatic leaves.
Includes rosemary, thyme, and basil.
The plant family of the coffee.
Includes gardenias and bedstraws.
Known for its opposite leaves and stipules.
The plant family of the carrots and parsley.
Known for its umbel-shaped flowers.
Also includes celery and dill.
The plant family of the grapes.
Known for its climbing vines and tendrils.
A very important family for wine.
The plant family of the heaths.
Includes blueberries, cranberries, and rhododendrons.
Often found in acidic soil.
The plant family of the phloxes.
Includes many ornamental plants.
Also known as the Jacob's ladder family.
The plant family of the plantains.
Includes foxgloves and snapdragons.
A diverse family of flowering plants.
The plant family of the verbenas.
Includes verbena and lemon verbena.
Known for its square stems and opposite leaves.
The plant family of the spurges.
Known for its milky latex.
Includes the castor bean plant.
A large group of flowering plants.
One of the two major clades of eudicots.
Includes the sunflower and mint families.
A large group of flowering plants.
One of the two major clades of eudicots.
Includes the rose and pea families.
A major group of flowering plants.
Have a single cotyledon in the seed.
Includes grasses, lilies, and orchids.
An older classification of flowering plants.
Have two cotyledons in the seed.
Now more accurately referred to as eudicots.
A modern classification of flowering plants.
The largest group of angiosperms.
Includes roses, oaks, and sunflowers.
The phylum of green algae.
They are the ancestors of land plants.
A large and diverse group.
The phylum of stoneworts.
The closest living relatives of land plants.
Also known as 'green algae'.
The study of fungi.
Fungi are not plants, but their study is often related.
This field studies mushrooms and yeast.
The study of lichens.
A specialized field of botany and mycology.
Studies the symbiotic relationship between a fungus and an alga.
A living organism of the kind typified by trees, shrubs, herbs, grasses, and ferns.
Typically grows in a permanent site, absorbing water and inorganic substances through its roots and synthesizing nutrients in its leaves by photosynthesis using the green pigment chlorophyll.
A living organism that performs photosynthesis.
A diverse group of aquatic organisms that have the ability to conduct photosynthesis.
They are not plants, but they are a related group.
Can be single-celled or multicellular.
A kingdom of organisms that includes mushrooms, yeasts, and molds.
They are not plants, as they do not perform photosynthesis.
They are decomposers.
A large domain of single-celled, prokaryotic microorganisms.
Some can perform photosynthesis.
They are decomposers.
A domain of single-celled organisms.
They are prokaryotes, and a different kingdom from bacteria.
Often found in extreme environments.
A single-celled organism that lacks a nucleus.
Includes bacteria and archaea.
Opposite of eukaryote.
An organism whose cells contain a nucleus.
Includes plants, animals, fungi, and protists.
Opposite of prokaryote.
A diverse group of eukaryotic organisms.
Includes algae and protozoa.
Most are single-celled, but some are multicellular.
The highest taxonomic rank.
Plants, animals, and fungi are three of these.
Part of the Linnaean classification system.
A taxonomic rank below kingdom and above class.
Chordata is the one for animals.
In botany, it is often called a division.
A taxonomic rank in botany, equivalent to phylum.
The division of plants.
A major group of plants.
A taxonomic rank below phylum and above order.
